Description: Fragmentary head of a limestone male figure. He wears a cap style with no visible outline between the hairline and neck. A thick band of black paint is visible on top of the cap and along the reverse. His proper left side of the face is now damaged, with his left eye now missing. His right eye is small with traces of black paint at the lower eyelid. There is a thin arched line above the eye. His nose is very broad, and the lips are thick and pursed. The outer corners of the mouth appear flat. His face is particularly broad around the jawline, and at the neck His ears are badly chipped and there is a gouge to the back of the head. The object is now attached to a small modern base.
Curator's comments: This head was recovered during the excavation of the temple of Mentuhotep II at Deir el-Bahari (Naville 1913; PM II). A photograph of the object is available to view online via Egypt Exploration Society's Flickr page: https://www.flickr.com/photos/egyptexplorationsociety/25113678908/in/album-72157663539521818/ (DB.NEG.09.336). A range of other votive figures dated to the New Kingdom, including head fragments, were also found during these excavations (e.g. EA 49053: https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/Y_EA40953; EA 40954: https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/Y_EA40954). General Sources: E. Naville, 1907-1913. The XIth dynasty temple at Deir el-Bahari. (London).
Bibliographic references: Porter and Moss 1972 / Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs, and Paintings 2: Theban Temples (p. 394)
